Institute for Integrated Cell-Material Sciences (iCeMS) Kyoto University Kyoto Japan Graphical abstract Single-atom alloy (SAA) attracts great interest recently as excellent heterogeneous catalyst. Herein, the catalysis of Ni-based Au SAA for NO-CO reaction is investigated using DFT calculations. Under lean conditions, N2 formation occurs to produce NiOx surface, as observed experimentally, because CO2 formation cannot occur due to easy desorption of CO. Under rich conditions, CO2 formation occurs with small E a value to afford (N)2-adsorbed surface. Next catalytic cycle starts with (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed surface because N2 formation needs larger E a value but NO adsorption readily occurs with considerable energy stabilization. As Au-content increases, d-valence-band center lowers in energy to increase activation barrier for N–O bond cleavage of NO but decrease those of CO2 and N2 formations. Thus, rate-limiting step is N2 formation in low Au-content but N–O bond cleavage in high Au-content. A volcano-plot is presented against Au-content. The optimal Au-content is about 6 % on catalyst surface. Keywords Ni-Au single-atom alloy DFT NO-CO reaction d-Valence band center Volcano-plot Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Recently, single-atom alloys (SAAs) composed of atomically dispersed precious metal atoms and base metal host [1–3] have been reported to exhibit excellent catalysis for propane dehydrogenation [4], ethanol dehydrogenation [5], and NO reduction [6]. SAA is expected to be a good three-way catalyst (TWC) without platinum group metal (PGM) elements such as platinum (Pt), palladium (Pd), and rhodium (Rh). Indeed, the amount of PGM elements has been reduced in TWCs by using SAAs [7–11]. Although number of gasoline vehicles must be decreased to solve the CO2 problem, they will be used for the next one ∼ two decades particularly in developing countries, deserts, and so on because of the lack of sufficient infrastructures for electricity supply. In addition, the use of gasoline vehicles is being reconsidered in several countries due to the shortage of electric power supply. Therefore, PGM-free TWCs must be developed in order to preserve resources on the earth and reduce costs by using SAA. In addition to being resource-saving, SAA has another advantage in that the addition of a second metal element to the host metal can control the electronic structure of the catalyst and improve its catalytic activity [12,13]. In this regard, various experimental efforts are underway to apply SAA to the NO-CO reaction which is important for exhaust gas purification [14–20]. Nickel (Ni) is more abundant on the earth than Pt, Pd, and Rh. Also, it has been experimentally reported that Ni metal, like Rh metal, is reactive to N–O bond cleavage of NO molecule [21]. However, Ni metal catalysts do not exhibit sufficient durability in TWC reaction because there exist two reasons for this: (i) they are easily oxidized and difficult to be regenerated unlike PGM catalysts [22,23], and (ii) they rapidly deactivate due to the formation of carbon on the surface under reaction conditions [24,25]. Consequently, the pure Ni metal is not useful as a catalyst for the NO-CO reaction. However, Au atoms in Ni-based Au alloy (named Ni-Au alloy, hereinafter) block edge and kink sites of the Ni surface from carbon formation to suppress the deactivation [24,25]. Also, Ni-based alloy can maintain the Ni metal phase and exhibit good catalytic performance for many reactions [26–33]. Therefore, Ni-based alloys are expected to be one of the promising PGM-free TWCs. For instance, Osaki et al. recently applied a Ni-Au alloy to NOx reduction [34]. Interestingly, the Ni-Au alloy exhibited much higher oxygen desorption efficiency than the well-known metallic Rh catalyst and N2 formation efficiency comparable to metallic Rh catalysts [35]. It is interesting that Au atoms play important role(s) to enhance the catalytic activity despite their inert nature. Many attempts have been made to understand the role(s) of Au atoms in Ni-Au alloy catalysts for the NO-CO reaction [36–41]. For instance, Watanabe et al. [38] developed a Ni(111)-based Au alloy with a small Au coverage (about 0.1 monolayer) and experimentally observed that N2 formation occurs at a higher temperature (543 K) than the formations of other products in the NO-CO reaction. Through DFT calculations, they also reported that O atoms preferentially occupy Ni hollow sites and concluded that only the N2 formation step was accelerated by Au atoms. Lambert et al. [39] demonstrated that Ni75Au25 catalyst exhibited higher activity for the NO-CO reaction than Ni50Au50 catalyst at low temperatures but a lower activity than Ni50Au50 at high temperatures because Au/Ni segregation occurred at high temperatures. It is noted that N2O yield was extremely small (less than 1 %) in the NO-CO reaction catalyzed by Ni-Au alloys [39]. These two groups reported that N2 formation was a rate-determining step (RDS) and its activation energy decreased by the presence of Au atoms [38,39]. Although experimental results showed that CO2 formation occurred at a lower temperature than does N2 formation [9,38], the presence of a NiOx phase on Ni-Au alloys was observed in some circumstances [39]. These observations provide us with one important open question: Why does the NiOx phase remain despite that CO2 formation occurs more readily than N2 formation? Several important elementary reaction steps in the NO-CO reaction have been investigated using such monometallic catalysts as Rh [42,43], Cu [44], and Fe2Ox [45] and such bimetallic catalysts as Pd- and Cu-based alloys [46,47]. In the NO-CO reaction catalyzed by Ni-based alloys, however, only a few of the elementary reaction steps have been theoretically investigated [38,39]. In addition to the open question regarding the formation of the NiOx phase mentioned above, we found several fundamentally important open questions: (i) Why are Au atoms effective in reducing an activation energy of N2 formation catalyzed by Ni-Au SAA despite their inert nature? (ii) To what extent are such important elementary reaction steps as N–O dissociative adsorption, CO2 formation, and N2 formation accelerated or suppressed by Au atoms and why? And, (iii) what is the optimal Au content for the NO-CO reaction? To obtain correct answers to these open questions, we theoretically investigated the NO-CO reaction catalyzed by pure Ni(111) and Ni(111)-based SAAs with Au atoms dispersed at atomic level (named nAu/Ni(111), n = the number of Au atoms in a supercell). Here, we explored all possible elementary reaction steps such as NO dissociative adsorption, CO2 formation, N2 formation, and N2O formation by the Ni(111) and nAu/Ni(111) catalysts. Our purposes here are to unveil characteristic features of the Ni-Au SAA catalyst in the NO-CO reaction, compare catalytic activity between the Ni(111) and the nAu/Ni(111) SAA catalysts, elucidate role(s) of Au atoms in this catalytic reaction, disclose the dependence of catalytic activity on the Au content, and find the optimal Au content. Particularly, we attempted to understand how much Au atoms affect the electronic structure of nAu/Ni(111) SAA and why the catalytic performance of nAu/Ni(111) is enhanced for the NO-CO reaction by atomically dispersed Au atoms compared to Ni(111). We believe that such theoretical knowledge provides us with valuable ideas for designing a new alloy catalyst. 2 Computational methods and models 2.1 Computational methods Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed under periodic boundary conditions using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [48]. Plane wave basis sets were employed with a kinetic-energy cutoff of 400 eV to represent valence electrons [49], and projector augmented wave pseudopotentials were used for core electrons [50]. Geometries were optimized with a maximum force threshold of 0.02 eV/Å and an energy change threshold of 10−4 eV [51,52]. Partial occupancies of orbitals (bands) were determined with the first-order Methfessel-Paxton scheme, where a smearing width of 0.2 eV was employed [53]. Although the dispersion correction influenced little Ni–C and C–O bond distances in the case of CO adsorption on Ni(111) [54], we added Grimme’s ‘‘D3(BJ)” dispersion correction [55,56] to the PBE functional considering two reasons below: (i) The dispersion correction influences adsorption energy of gas molecule; for instance, the correction increases the CO adsorption energy from –1.92 eV to –2.14 eV. And, (ii) lateral interactions between co-adsorbed species are important to investigate the surface reaction. Transition states were first searched using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method by Henkelman et al. [57–59] and then optimized using the improved dimer (IDM) method by Heyden et al. [60,61]. Vibrational frequency analysis was performed at the same level of theory to confirm that a transition state is a saddle point with only one imaginary frequency along the reaction direction and an equilibrium structure does not have any imaginary frequency, where the metal moiety was fixed to save computational time. The density of states (DOS) was calculated with the Gaussian smearing scheme (smearing width = 0.1 eV) within a k-point grid of 4 × 4 × 1. The Bader charges were calculated using the program developed by Henkelman et al. [62]. Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) was used for these calculations [63,64]. Because the entropy change ΔS is considerably large in the adsorption of gaseous X molecule to surface and the desorption of adsorbed X molecule from surface to gas phase, the Gibbs energy change ΔG was employed for discussion in those steps like in our previous work [65]. The Gibbs energy G X of isolated gaseous X molecule was calculated using eq. (1a); (1a) G X T , P X = G X ° ( T ) + R T l n ( P X / P 0 ) (1b) G X ° (T) = E tot + ZPE + Δ E therm(trans, rot, vib) + Δ S (trans, rot, vib) T + P Δ V where the PX was taken to be 1.0 atm, the E tot is DFT-calculated total energy, the ZPE is zero-point energy, the Δ E therm(trans, rot, vib) is thermal energy, the ΔS (trans, rot, vib) is entropy, and the subscript (trans, rot, vib) represents contribution from translational, rotational, and vibrational movements. The E tot was calculated using VASP, as described above, where the X molecule was placed in the large box (30 Å x 30 Å x 30 Å). The other terms were calculated using Gaussian16 program [66]; details are described in page S3 of the Supporting Information (SI). The Gibbs energy of X adsorbent was evaluated using eqs. (1c) and (1d); (1c) G X T = E tot + ZPE + Δ G X 0 → T K (1d) Δ G X 0 → T K = G vib T = ∑ i - k T ln 1 1 - exp ( - h v i k b T ) where ν i is the frequency of the i-th vibrational state; additional explanation is presented in page S3 of the SI. We evaluated frequencies at the same level of theory mentioned above using VASP program. For discussing other elementary reaction steps which occur on the Ni-Au alloy surface without adsorption and desorption of X molecule, the DFT-calculated total energy difference between a transition state and the most stable intermediate before the transition state was used as an activation barrier (E a). This means that changes in zero-point energy, thermal energy, and entropy by vibrations are neglected in the E a value of the surface reaction. This approximation is not unlikely because the DFT-calculated total energy change does not differ very much from the Gibbs free energy change when all the species are adsorbed on catalyst surface and neither adsorption nor desorption of molecule takes place; Table S1 of the SI shows comparisons between the Gibbs energy of activation and the activation barrier (E a) of N–O bond cleavage, N2 formation, and CO2 formation. In this work, we discussed the energy change at the temperature (T) of 500 K, which is close to the experimental conditions [34,39]. 2.2 Models The optimized lattice constant of bulk Ni crystal is 3.520 Å for fcc-Ni with a k-point grid of 9 × 9 × 9. This value agrees well with the experimental value (3.52 Å) of fcc-Ni [67]. For the Ni(111) catalyst, we used a small slab model (named Ni(111)S) composed of 5-layer atoms and 4 × 4 supercell and a large slab model (named Ni(111)L) composed of the 4-layer atoms and 6 × 6 supercell, as shown in Scheme 1 , where the subscripts “S” and “L” represent respectively a small slab model and a large one, hereinafter. In both slab models, a vacuum layer of 15 Å was employed for calculation. For the Ni-Au SAA catalyst, we constructed nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 1 ∼ 3) and nAu/Ni(111)L (n = 1 ∼ 4, 6, 8, 9, 11, 12) slab models on the basis of the Ni(111)S and Ni(111)L slab models, respectively, by replacing n Ni atoms on the surface with n Au atoms because the surface segregation energy of Au solute in Ni(111) host is negative [68]. In the model, Au atoms are separately placed (Scheme 1) because experimental works [38,39,69] revealed that Au atoms are atomically dispersed on the top-layer of Ni(111) to afford SAA and such a dispersed structure is supported by our previous theoretical work [54]. However, only 12Au/Ni(111)S is not SAA because several Au–Au bonds exist on the surface due to the presence of overly many Au atoms. All the optimized structures of nAu/Ni(111)L are presented in Figs S1–S7 of the SI. Considering large computational costs, the small model nAu/Ni(111)S was used to explore the NO-CO reaction because numerous intermediates and transition states must be optimized. The large model nAu/Ni(111)L was employed to investigate how much the activation barrier of each elementary reaction step depends on the Au content. In geometry optimizations of nAu/Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)L, the top three layers and adsorbed species were relaxed and the remaining moiety was fixed at their equilibrium positions in the bulk metal. The Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid of 3 × 3 × 1 was used for the small slab models nAu/Ni(111)S and that of 2 × 2 × 1 was used for the large models nAu/Ni(111)L. To check whether adsorbate-induced inverse of surface segregation occurs or not, we calculated the segregation energy of one Au atom in Au/Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S in the presence of adsorbed NO and CO molecules and found that the adsorbate-induced inverse of surface segregation does not occur; Table S2 and page S5 of the SI present computational results and discussion, respectively. At the end of this section, we discuss the limits and weak points of the present models. Because NO and CO adsorption energies are significantly negative, as described below, the surface coverage would be high. However, the coverage of our model was assumed not to be high like in many computational works, indicating that the present model is not exactly the same as a real system. Because the coverage influences the electronic structure of the surface such as charge, d-band center, and the Fermi level, flexibility of adsorption positions, and lateral interaction among adsorbed species, these properties differ between the present model and real system: In other words, these adsorbate-induced changes in the surface electronic structure, the flexibility of adsorption site, and the lateral interaction are missing in our model. Although the present models are not perfect, it is likely that the present models provide us with the knowledge on the effects of Au atoms on the NO-CO reaction; for instance, the present models are useful for elucidating whether or not Au atoms decrease the activation energies of N2 and CO2 formations and whether or not they increase the activation energy of N–O bond cleavage, and so on. 3 Nomenclatures Many kinds of surfaces are studied here and the NO-CO reaction proceeds through many kinds of intermediates and transition states in several possible reaction pathways in each model. As a result, the naming of intermediates and transition states is not simple because there exist many species to be discussed. Table 1 summarises their names for ease of understanding. In addition, model A1 stands for the Ni(111)S catalyst and models A2 ∼ A4 represent the nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 1 ∼ 3) catalysts, as shown in Scheme 1. Models B1 ∼ B10 represent the nAu/Ni(111)L (n = 0 ∼ 4, 6, 8, 9, 11, and 12) catalysts. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Adsorptions of NO and CO molecules and N and O atoms on nAu/Ni(111)S We firstly investigated adsorptions of gaseous NO and CO molecules on nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 0 ∼ 3) catalysts. The Ni(111)S catalyst has several possible adsorption sites such as fcc hollow (Hf ), hcp hollow (Hh ), bridge (B), and on-top (OT) sites, as shown by Scheme 1(a). The hollow sites (Hf and Hh ) surrounded by three Ni atoms are named 3NiHf and 3NiHh and the bridge site between two Ni atoms is named 2NiB hereinafter. The adsorption energies (BE in eV) of NO and CO molecules increase (get more negative) in the order OT < B < Hh ∼ Hf , as shown in Table S3 of the SI, indicating that their adsorptions occur first at the fcc and hcp hollow sites (Hf and Hh ), where BE is evaluated using DFT-calculated total energies because such a BE value is useful to discussing relative stabilities of gas adsorptions at these sites. The BE values for NO and CO adsorptions at the Hf site are –2.75 eV and –2.14 eV, respectively, as shown in Table 2 , where a negative value represents a stabilization energy. These values are more negative than the values reported by Watanabe et al. (–1.79 eV and –1.81 eV, respectively) [38], probably because the dispersion correction was added in this work but not in their work. In the nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 1 ∼ 3) case, the adsorption sites are classified into two types, as shown in Scheme 1(a): In one, the Au atom(s) directly participates in the adsorption, which is named Hf0 , Hh0 , B0 , or OT0 using the subscript “0”. The other sites, in which the Au atom(s) does not, are denoted as Hfm , Hhm , Bm , and OTm (m = integer larger than 0; see Scheme 1(a)), where the larger m means a more distant site from the Au atom. We investigated the adsorptions of NO and CO molecules as well as N and O atoms at the Hf0 , Hh0 , B0 , and OT0 sites adjacent to the Au atom on nAu/Ni(111)S catalysts. However, all the adsorbed species move from these sites to the nearest 3NiHf1 or 3NiHh1 site during geometry optimization, as shown in Table S3 of the SI. This is reasonable because the presence of Au atoms is not favorable for CO and NO adsorptions, as discussed below. These computational results are consistent with the experimental observation showing that NO and CO adsorptions at the on-top Au site have not been observed [38,70]. We thus excluded their adsorptions at the Hf0 , Hh0 , B0 , and OT0 sites in all the nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 1 ∼ 3) catalysts. Also, we explored their adsorptions at the 2NiB1 and 2NiB2 sites next to the Au atom and found that NO and CO move from these sites to the nearest 3NiHfn or 3NiHhn site, which are more distant from the Au atom than B1 , B2 , and OT1 sites, during geometry optimization, as shown in Table S3 of the SI. Although NO and CO can be adsorbed at the OT1 site with BE values of –1.78 eV and –1.77 eV, respectively, their BE values are smaller than at 3NiHfn and 3NiHhn sites (Table S3). Therefore, the OT1 site is ruled out from plausible adsorption sites and 3NiHfn and 3NiHhn (n > 1) sites are investigated for adsorptions of NO and CO molecules. In 3NiHfn / 3NiHhn , there exist three kinds of adsorption sites such as 3NiHf1 ∼ 3NiHf3 / 3NiHh1 ∼ 3NiHh3 on the Au/Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S surfaces, and two kinds such as 3NiHf1 and 3NiHf2 / 3NiHh1 and 3NiHh2 on the 3Au/Ni(111)S surface, as shown by A2 ∼ A4 in Scheme 1(a). As shown by the BE values listed in Table S3 of the SI, the most stable adsorption site for these adsorbates is either 3NiHfn or 3NiHhn (n > 1). These sites are the most distant from the Au atom; for instance, the most stable adsorption site is 3NiHf3 on the Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S surfaces, and 3NiHf2 on the 3Au/Ni(111)S surface. The BE values of these adsorbates increase (get more negative) as the adsorption site becomes more distant from the Au atom (Table S3 of the SI). The BE value at the most stable adsorption site is listed in Table 2. The BE (NO) value of the most stable NO adsorption is more negative than the BE (CO) value of the most stable CO adsorption, and the BE (O) value of the most stable O atom adsorption is more negative than the BE (N) value of the most stable N atom adsorption. As going from Au/Ni(111)S to 3Au/Ni(111)S, the BE value decreases (gets less negative) by 0.11 eV, 0.06 eV, 0.17 eV, and 0.19 eV in the NO, CO, N, and O absorptions, respectively. It is clearly concluded that the presence of Au atom(s) suppresses adsorptions of all these species and weakens the N and O adsorptions more than the NO and CO adsorptions. The Bader charges indicate that these adsorbates are negatively charged and their negative charges decrease as the number of Au atoms increases (Table 2). These features indicate that charge transfer (CT) occurs from the nAu/Ni(111)S catalyst to these adsorbates, and that the CT weakens as the number of Au atoms increases, the reason for which is discussed below in detail. Although N and O atoms are strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, they migrate from one 3NiHf site to another 3NiHf site with a moderate activation barrier (E a = 0.52 eV ∼ 0.61 eV) on all the nAu/Ni(111)S catalyst, as shown in Table S4 of the SI. The moderate E a values imply that N and O atoms migrate easily on the surface during the NO-CO reaction. Because of the easy migrations of these species on the surface, we did not discuss their migrations in the NO-CO reaction. 4.2 NO–CO reaction network In the NO-CO reaction, two kinds of reaction occur generally, as described by Eqs. (2) and (3); (2) 2NO (g) + 2CO (g) → N2 (g) + 2CO2 (g) (3) 2NO (g) + CO (g) → N2O (g) + CO2 (g) In the case of the Ni-Au SAA catalyst, NO and CO are mainly converted to N2 and CO2, while N2O is produced as a minor product [38,39]. In this work, therefore, we focused on Eq. (2) but also explored the N2O formation via Eq. (3). Because it is difficult to know the exact coverage and/or the ratio of NO and CO molecules adsorbed on the Ni-Au SAA catalyst under the catalytic reaction conditions, we investigated the NO-CO reaction starting from the adsorptions of two NO molecules on the catalyst for reasons below; (i) the BE value of the NO adsorption is larger than that of the CO adsorption (Table 2), (ii) on the Ni metal surface, NO dissociative adsorption occurs at the room temperature more easily than the other elementary reaction steps [22,39,71], strongly suggesting that the NO dissociative adsorption occurs easily, and (iii) two NO molecules are necessary at least for formations of N2 and N2O. Considering the above conditions, we investigated all possible reaction courses shown in Scheme 2 . Because there exist many elementary reaction steps, we firstly explain the main reaction course shown by solid lines. The first step is the adsorptions of two NO molecules on the surface of Ni-Au SAA 1 to afford an (NO)2-adsorbed system 2; here we did not consider that the N−O bond cleavage of the first adsorbed NO molecule occurs before the second NO adsorption because the NO adsorption occurs with a significantly negative ΔG value but the N−O bond cleavage needs an activation energy to pass through a transition state, as described below. In the next step, one end-on adsorbed NO molecule is converted to a side-on adsorbed NO to afford an (NO)(NO)-adsorbed system 3 followed by its N–O bond cleavage to afford an (NO)(N)(O)-adsorbed system 4, where the underline of NO represents that N and O atoms interact with the surface. Starting from 4, one more N–O bond cleavage occurs via a similar side-on adsorbed NO molecule (named 5A ) to afford an (N)2(O)2-adsorbed system 6. The first CO molecule is adsorbed on the surface of 6 to afford an (N)2(O)2(CO)-adsorbed system 7. Starting from 7, either CO2 formation or N2 formation is possible to occur. We explored both the CO2 formation (7→8A ) and the N2 formation (7→8B ) (Scheme 2), where the subscripts A and B represent CO2 formation and N2 formation, respectively. The CO2 formation more easily occurs than the N2 formation when CO concentration is enough (under the rich conditions), as discussed below. Starting from (N)2(O)(CO2)-adsorbed system 8A , CO2 desorbs easily from the catalyst surface to afford an (N)2(O)-adsorbed system 9 because the CO2 molecule is weakly adsorbed on the metal surface generally. Then, the second CO molecule is adsorbed on 9 to afford (N)2(O)(CO)-adsorbed system 10. Starting from 10, either CO2 or N2 formation occurs in the next step. We investigated both (10→11A and 10→11B ) and found that the CO2 formation more easily occurs than the N2 formation under the rich conditions. After the second CO2 formation (10→11A ), CO2 desorbs easily from the surface to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system 12. In the last step, N2 formation occurs to afford an (N2)-adsorbed system 13. Finally, the N2 molecule desorbs from the surface to regenerate the original catalyst 1. This reaction course shown by the solid line is possible under the rich conditions, as described in the next section. Because the very small yield of N2O observed experimentally [38,39] suggests strongly that the formation of the ON-NO dimer followed by N−O bond cleavage is unlikely to occur, we did not involve this step in Scheme 2. When CO concentration is tinny (very strong lean conditions), CO adsorption is difficult to occur. In such a case, only N2 formation occurs starting from 6 to afford an (N2)(O)2-adsorbed system 14. Even under the lean conditions, CO adsorption on 6 may occur to afford 7 because the CO adsorption is exergonic, if some extent of CO is involved in gas. Starting from 7, however, the CO2 formation is not easy to occur because the CO desorption more easily occurs than the CO2 formation, as described in the next section. Therefore, only N2 formation can occur starting from 7 concomitantly with CO desorption to afford 14 under the lean conditions because the activation barrier for N2 formation is larger than the CO desorption energy, as discussed below. This means that 14 is formed from 6 and 7 under the lean conditions either with or without CO adsorption. Starting from 14, the N2 molecule easily desorbs from the surface because the N2 adsorption energy is generally small. Therefore, an (O)2-adsorbed system 15 is produced. To regenerate the initial catalyst, these O atoms must react with CO to afford CO2 molecules. We investigated the first CO adsorption followed by CO2 formation (15→16→17 in Scheme 2 left-side) and the second CO adsorption followed by CO2 formation (18→19→20). It is likely that these CO2 formations are difficult to occur under the lean conditions because CO adsorption is not easy due to its smaller adsorption energy than the NO adsorption energy and the CO desorption energy is smaller than the E a value for the CO2 formation, as discussed below. However, we investigated these steps to know whether the CO2 formation is accelerated by the presence of Au atoms or not. In addition, we investigated whether or not N2O molecule is produced from (NO)(N)(O)-adsorbed system 4 to afford an (N2O)(O)-adsorbed system 21. Because the reaction course depends on the CO concentration, all these elementary steps are discussed below under both rich and lean conditions. 4.3 NO-CO reaction on 2Au/Ni(111)S and Ni(111)S surfaces We discuss here each elementary reaction step shown in Scheme 2 using the 2Au/Ni(111)S catalyst in comparison with the Ni(111)S catalyst to disclose the most favorable reaction course by these catalysts. The geometry changes along the reaction pathway by these catalysts are presented in Figs. S8 and S9 of the SI, respectively. 4.3.1 NO adsorption followed by N–O bond cleavage Two NO molecules are adsorbed on Ni(111)S 1Ni at the Hf site in an end-on adsorption manner to afford an (NO)2-adsorbed system 2Ni with a significantly negative Gibbs energy change (ΔG 2NO = –4.09 eV), as shown in Fig. 1 , where the subscript “Ni” of 2 represents intermediates or transition states derived from 1Ni hereinafter. In the next step, the end-on adsorption structure of one NO molecule changes to a side-on adsorption structure to afford an (NO)(NO)-adsorbed system 3Ni with a moderate destabilization energy of 0.58 eV. The N–O bond lengthens to 1.271 Å in the side-on adsorbed NO molecule. Then, the N–O bond cleavage occurs through a transition site TS(3/4)Ni to afford an (NO)(N)(O)-adsorbed system 4Ni with an activation barrier E a(2→4) of 1.33 eV and a reaction energy E r(2→4) of –0.94 eV. In TS(3/4)Ni , the N and O atoms of the reacting NO molecule are bound with the Hf and B sites, respectively, and the N–O distance further lengthens to 1.686 Å. After the N–O bond cleavage, the O atom moves to an Hf site which is distant from the adsorbed NO and N species. The co-adsorbed NO molecule influences little the first N−O bond cleavage, as shown by the fact that the E a(2→4) value differs little between the presence of one NO molecule (E a = 1.33 eV) and the absence (E a = 1.34 eV). The second N–O bond cleavage occurs in a similar manner via an (NO)(N)(O)-adsorbed system 5Ni to afford an (N)2(O)2-adsorbed system 6Ni , where moderate differences are observed in energy changes between the first and the second N−O bond cleavages, as discussed below. In 2Au/Ni(111)S 1Au , NO adsorption and N–O bond cleavage occur in a similar manner to those in the Ni(111)S case, as shown in Fig. 1. However, several moderate differences are observed: For instance, the sum of adsorption energies of two NO molecules (−4.00 eV) is slightly smaller (less negative) in 2Au/Ni(111)S than in Ni(111)S (−4.09 eV) and the E a values for the first and the second N–O bond cleavages (1.41 eV and 1.51 eV, respectively) are moderately larger in 2Au/Ni(111)S than in the Ni(111)S case (1.33 eV and 1.36 eV, respectively). Consistent with the larger E a value, the reaction energies of the first and the second N–O bond cleavages (–0.68 eV and –0.53 eV relative to 2Au ) are less negative (less exothermic) in 2Au/Ni(111)S than in the Ni(111)S case (–0.94 eV and –0.81 eV), the reason of which is discussed below. The slightly larger E a and the slightly less negative E r values in the 2Au/Ni(111)S case than in the Ni(111)S case indicate that the N–O bond cleavage is suppressed kinetically and thermodynamically by the presence of Au atoms on the Ni(111)S surface. These results agree with the experimental report by Lambert et al. [39] showing that the initial rate of NO consumption at the low temperature (200 ℃ ∼ 280 ℃) is slower in the Ni75Au25 case than in the pure Ni case. The NO moieties are negatively charged in 2 and 4 and get more negative upon going from 2 to 4 and from 4 to 6, as presented in Table S5 of the SI. This is reasonable because the N–O bond cleavage needs injection of electron density into the lowest energy unoccupied antibonding molecule orbital (LUMO) of NO. As a result of this CT from the catalyst to NO in the first N–O bond cleavage, the CT weakens in the second N–O bond cleavage. Therefore, the second N–O bond cleavage (4→5→6) occurs with a larger E a value (1.36 eV and 1.51 eV relative to 4Ni and 4Au , respectively) and a less negative E r value (–0.94 eV and –0.68 eV relative to 4Ni and 4Au , respectively) than those for the first N–O bond cleavage (E a = 1.33 eV and 1.41 eV and E r = –0.94 eV and –0.68 eV relative to 2Ni and 2Au , respectively). 4.3.2 The first CO2 formation vs the first N2 formation Starting from the (N)2(O)2-adsorbed system 6Ni , the first CO molecule is adsorbed on 6 Ni at the Hh site to afford an (N)2(O)2(CO)-adsorbed system 7Ni (Scheme 2) with a ΔG value of –1.30 eV, as shown in Fig. 2 , where details in geometry changes are shown in Fig. S8 of the SI. There exist two possible reactions starting from 7Ni ; one is CO2 formation and the other is N2 formation. In the CO2 formation, the adsorbed CO molecule reacts with one O atom adsorbed at the Hf site to afford a (CO2)(N)2(O)-adsorbed system 8Ni through a transition state TS(7/8)A-Ni . In TS(7/8)A-Ni , the OCO angle is 117°, and the C–O distance d (C-O) is 1.637 Å, where the O and C atoms are adsorbed at the Hf and B sites, respectively. These geometrical parameters indicate that the CO2 moiety in the transition state much differs from a free CO2 molecule. This step occurs with an E a(7→8Ni ) value of 1.35 eV and a considerably positive E r value of 0.98 eV. Because the E a(7→8Ni ) value is larger than the CO desorption energy (1.30 eV), CO desorbs more easily than CO2 being produced. These results strongly suggest that the CO2 formation occurs under the rich conditions but hardly under the lean conditions, which is discussed below in more details. The N2 formation starting from 7Ni occurs through a transition state TS(7/8)B-Ni to afford an (N2)(O)2(CO)-adsorbed system 8Ni-B with an E a(7→8) value of 1.67 eV. In TS(7/8)B-Ni , the N–N distance is 1.762 Å (Fig. S8 of the SI), indicating that the N–N distance is much longer than that of a free N2 molecule. Because this E a value is larger than the CO desorption energy, the N2 formation occurs simultaneously with CO desorption to afford an (N2)(O)2-adsorbed system 14Ni . Because 14Ni can be formed from 6Ni through N2 formation, we also investigated the N2 formation starting from 6Ni . This reaction occurs through a transition state TS(6/14)Ni to reach 14Ni . Because TS(6/14)Ni is at a lower energy than TS(5/6)Ni by 0.38 eV, the forward N2 formation from 6Ni to 14Ni occurs more easily than the reverse reaction (6Ni→4Ni ), even though the E a value (1.78 eV) of the N2 formation is considerably large. Starting from 14Ni , the N2 molecule desorbs easily from the catalyst surface to afford an (O)2-adsorbed system 15Ni because the N2 adsorption is generally weak. The total E r value relative to 6Ni is –0.23 eV. In 2Au/Ni(111)S, CO adsorption, CO2 formation, and N2 formation occur in similar manners to those in the Ni(111)S case, as shown in Fig. 3 , whereas the energy changes moderately differ from those in the Ni(111)S case. For instance, the CO adsorption energy (−1.15 eV) is smaller in the 2Au/Ni(111)S case than in the Ni(111)s case (−1.30 eV), and the E a(7→8) value (1.25 eV) is smaller and the E r value (0.80 eV) is less positive in the 2Au/Ni(111)S case than in the Ni(111)S case (1.35 eV and 0.98 eV, respectively). Also, the E a(6→14) value (1.67 eV) is smaller and the E r(6→14) value (−0.56 eV) is more negative in the 2Au/Ni(111)S case than in the Ni(111)S case (1.78 eV and −0.23 eV, respectively). These results indicate that the presence of Au atoms inhibits CO adsorption but promotes the formations of N2 and CO2. The differences in energy changes between 2Au/Ni(111)S and Ni(111)S cases are discussed below in more details. The other differences are found in the adsorption positions: For instance, the first CO adsorption on the (N)2(O)2-adsorbed system 6Au occurs at the position rather close to the adsorbed O atom in 7Au , whereas the first CO molecule is adsorbed at the distant site from the O atom in 7Ni ; details in geometry changes are shown in Figs. S8 and S9 of the SI. These results indicate that the adsorption positions are limited in 2Au/Ni(111)S compared to the Ni(111)S case. The selectivity, CO2 formation vs N2 formation, depends on their E a values, CO desorption energy, and reaction conditions because the activation barrier E a(7→8A ) for CO2 formation is smaller than the E a(7→8B ) for N2 formation but the CO desorption energy (7→6) is slightly smaller than the activation barrier E a(7→8A ) for the CO2 formation (Figs. 2 and 3). Under the rich conditions with high partial pressure and high concentration of CO, CO desorption is suppressed and/or CO2 formation occurs through the Eley-Rideal mechanism more easily than the N2 formation to afford an (N)2(O)(CO2)-adsorbed system 8A because the E a(7→8A ) value for the CO2 formation is significantly smaller than the E a(7→8B ) value for the N2 formation in both Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S cases (Figs. 2 and 3); it should be noted here that the transition state of the Eley-Rideal mechanism does not always resemble TS(7/8) but would resemble TS(7/8) in some case, for instance, when CO approaches the O atom in a direction close to the surface. Under the lean conditions, however, CO adsorption is difficult to occur because the concentration of CO is smaller than that of NO and the adsorption energy of NO is somewhat larger than that of CO. Also, CO desorbs easily due to its smaller concentration and the CO2 formation needs a slightly larger E a value than the CO desorption energy. Although the CO2 formation cannot be ruled out completely because of the small energy difference between the E a value for the CO2 formation and the CO desorption energy, it is likely concluded that the CO2 formation is not easy to occur under the lean condition. Therefore, the N2 formation mainly occurs starting from 6 or 7 to afford an (O)2-adsorbed system 15 under the lean conditions despite its large activation barrier, as shown in Scheme 2. Certainly, Watanabe et al. [38] and Mavrikakis et al. [72] reported that CO2 formation was not observed from the CO and O co-adsorbed surface in both Ni(111) and Ni-Au alloy cases when the CO pressure was low. However, CO2 formation was observed when CO pressure was high [38]. Asakura et al. also reported that NiOx and Cu/NiOx were observed in the NO-CO reaction under the lean conditions but were not under the rich conditions [40]. The present computational results are consistent with their experimental observations. 4.3.3 The second CO2 formation in competition with N2 formation Starting from 8A, the first CO2 desorption occurs to afford an (N)2(O)-adsorbed system 9A with a negative ΔG value (8A → 9A ) in both Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S cases (−0.41 eV and −0.53 eV respectively; Figs. 2 and 3), because CO2 does not strongly interact with the metal surface generally. After the CO2 desorption, the second CO molecule is adsorbed on the (N)2(O)-adsorbed system 9 (Scheme 2) to afford an (N)2(O)(CO)-adsorbed system 10 with a negative ΔG value (Figs. 2 and 3). Then, the CO molecule reacts with an adsorbed O atom to generate an (N)2(CO2)-adsorbed system 11A through a transition state TS(10/11)A with an E a value of 1.45 eV (1.37 eV) and a considerably positive E r value of 1.07 eV (0.90 eV), where energy changes of Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S are presented without parentheses and in parentheses, respectively, hereinafter. These E a values are slightly larger than the CO desorption energy, indicating that the second CO2 molecule is produced under the rich conditions but is not easily under the lean conditions like the first CO2 molecule, as discussed above. The geometry of TS(10/11)A for the second CO2 formation resembles that of TS(7/8)A for the first CO2 formation (Figs. 2 and 3). The second CO2 desorption occurs easily to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system 12A with a negative ΔG value of –0.41 eV (–0.59 eV) like the first CO2 desorption. Starting from 10, the N2 formation through a transition state TS(10/11)B needs a considerably larger E a value of 1.79 eV (1.70 eV) than that of the CO2 formation by 0.35 eV (0.33 eV). Therefore, it should be concluded that the second CO2 formation occurs more easily than the N2 formation to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system under the rich conditions. Then, CO2 desorption easily occurs in 11 to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system 12. Starting from 12, N2 formation occurs as a final step of the catalytic cycle through a transition state TS(12/13) with an E a(12→13) value of 1.90 eV (1.81 eV) and an E r(12→13) value of –0.04 eV (–0.17 eV). This E a value is the largest in the catalytic cycle, indicating that the N2 formation is a rate-limiting step. The above results are summarized, as follows: The N2 formation needs a larger E a value than the second CO2 formation. Under the lean conditions, however, the CO adsorption less easily occurs than the NO adsorption due to the small concentration and the smaller CO adsorption energy than the NO one, and the CO desorption occurs easily because its desorption energy is smaller than the E a value for the CO2 formation in both Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S catalysts. Thus, the CO2 formation is difficult to occur and the O atoms remain on the surface under the lean conditions, as observed experimentally [38,40,72] and discussed above. Under the rich conditions, CO2 formation occurs more easily than N2 formation to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system. Here, we discuss the reason(s) why the N2 formation needs the larger E a value than the CO2 formation because this is important for determining the reaction mechanism. The larger E a value for the N2 formation than for the CO2 formation results from factors below: (i) Because N2 and CO2 molecules are neutral and adsorbed N and O atoms are negatively charged on the surface, the CT from the catalyst to these adsorbates must weaken as N2 and CO2 formations proceed. The Bader charges show that the CT occurs more strongly from the catalyst to two adsorbed N atoms at the transition states of the N2 formation than to the adsorbed O and CO species at the transition state of the CO2 formation, as shown in Table S6 of the SI. Therefore, the N2 formation is more difficult to occur than the CO2 formation. And, (ii) the integrated projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (IpCOHP) value for the O–CO interaction is more negative than that for the N–N interaction at the transition state, as shown in Table S6 of the SI, indicating that the O–CO bonding interaction is stronger than the N–N one at the transition state. The stronger O–CO bonding interaction than the N–N one is reasonably understood in terms of two factors below: In one, the position of the adsorbed CO molecule is more flexible than that of the adsorbed N atom because of the weaker interaction of the CO molecule with the surface than that of the N atom. In the other, the adsorbed N atom more strongly interacts with the catalyst surface than CO, and therefore, it does not form a strong bonding interaction with the other species. These features lead to the conclusion that the N2 formation is intrinsically more difficult to occur than the CO2 formation. 4.3.4 N2O formation vs N−O bond cleavage Starting from the (NO)(N)(O)-adsorbed systems 4Ni and 4Au , the adsorbed NO molecule undergoes either N2O formation or N–O bond cleavage. The N2O formation occurs through a transition state TS(4/19) with an E a value of 1.98 eV (1.84 eV) and a considerably positive ΔE r value of 1.64 eV (1.69 eV), as shown in Fig. 4 . Because the E a value for the N–O bond cleavage (1.36 eV and 1.51 eV for TS(5/6)Ni and TS(5/6)Au , respectively; Fig. 1) is smaller than that for the N2O formation, the N2O formation is difficult to occur starting from 4Ni and 4Au , but the N–O bond cleavage occurs instead. These computational results agree with the experimental findings that N2 and CO2 are main products but the yield of N2O is small in the NO-CO reaction catalyzed by the Ni-Au alloy catalyst [38–40]. 4.3.5 Summary of NO-CO reaction In all the Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)S cases, the NO-CO reaction proceeds, as described below: NO adsorption occurs first followed by the N–O bond cleavage; 1→2→3→4→5→6 (Scheme 2; blue lines). Then, the reaction pathway depends on the reaction conditions. Under the rich conditions, CO2 formation occurs two times, and then N2 formation occurs as the last step, as shown by 6→7→8→9→10→11→12→13→1 (Scheme 2; black lines). The energy changes are shown in Fig. 5 (a) and Table S7 in the SI, indicating that the E a and E r values depend on the number (n) of Au atoms on the surface. In all the Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)S cases, the last N2 formation is a rate-limiting step. Under the lean conditions, CO2 formation is difficult to occur because CO desorbs easily from the surface with a slightly smaller desorption energy than the E a value of the CO2 formation (Fig. 6 (a) and Table S8 of the SI) and also CO adsorption is suppressed by NO adsorption due to the smaller adsorption energy of CO than that of NO. When the CO desorption occurs and/or the CO adsorption is suppressed, only the N2 formation occurs even with the large E a value to produce the (O)2-adsorbed surface, as experimentally reported [34,40]. Thus, the NO-CO reaction proceeds via 6→14→15→16 under the lean conditions (Scheme 2; red line). Though the reaction stops at 16, we investigated further reaction of the (O)2-adsorbed system 16 with two CO molecules to check if CO2 formation is accelerated by the presence of Au atoms. The presence of Au atoms decreases the E a value of the CO2 formation (Fig. 6(a)), which is discussed below again. 4.4 Effects of Au atoms on each elementary step In this section, we investigated the effects of Au atoms on all the elementary reaction steps by nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 0 ∼ 3) catalysts; the changes of geometries and energies in the NO-CO reaction are shown in Figs. S10–S13 of the SI. The E a values for several important elementary steps under the rich conditions are plotted against the number of Au atoms on the Ni(111)S surface, as shown in Fig. 5(b). Apparently, the E a value for the N2 formation is much larger than those of the N–O bond cleavage and the CO2 formation, indicating clearly that the N2 formation is a rate-limiting step. The second N–O bond cleavage and the second CO2 formation occur with larger E a values and less negative (or more positive) E r values than those of the first ones (Fig. 5(b) and 5(c)). This is reasonable as follows; the metal surface is partially oxidated after the first N–O bond cleavage, which is unfavorable for the second N–O bond cleavage because CT occurs from the catalyst to NO in the N−O bond cleavage. After the first CO2 formation, the surface is partially reduced, which is unfavorable for the second CO2 formation because CT occurs from the O and CO species to the catalyst in the CO2 formation to suppress the CT in the second CO2 formation step. The most important result is that the E a value for the N–O bond cleavage increases but the E a values for CO2 formation and N2 formation decrease as the number of Au atoms increases. Because the N2 formation is a rate-limiting step, the presence of Au atoms on Ni(111)S accelerates the NO-CO reaction under the rich conditions. The E a and E r values under the lean conditions are plotted against the number of Au atoms in Fig. 6(b) and (c). The N2 formation needs the largest E a value, indicating that this is a rate-limiting step. The E a values for N2 formation and CO2 formation decrease, the E r value for N2 formation gets more negative, and that for the CO2 formation gets less positive, as the number of Au atoms increases (Fig. 6(b) and (c)). These trends are the same as those in the rich conditions. Because the N2 formation is a rate-limiting step, it is concluded that the presence of Au atoms accelerates the NO-CO reaction under the lean conditions, too. The durability under the lean conditions is also one of the important issues for the Ni-based catalyst. At 500 K, the E a value for the CO2 formation is slightly larger than the CO desorption energy in both Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S. At a lower temperature, however, the CO desorption energy becomes larger than the E a value for the CO2 formation in both Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S because the TΔS term decreases, as shown in Fig. S14 of the SI. Because the presence of Au atoms in nAu/Ni(111)S decreases the E a value for CO2 formation, the Au atoms improve the durability of the Ni-based Au SAA at lower temperatures, which is consistent with the experimental result [38,39]. In order to explore the relations between the Au coverage, the electronic structure, and the reactivity of this SAA in detail, we investigated model reactions such as N–O bond cleavage of one NO molecule, CO2 formation from one O atom and one CO molecule, and N2 formation from two N atoms on nAu/Ni(111)L, using a large model nAu/Ni(111)L: Figs. S15–S17 of the SI show geometry changes in these reactions and Table S9 of the SI presents the Bader charges, bond distances, and electronic structures (the Fermi level and d-valence band center). The Au atoms on the Ni(111) host are negatively charged, indicating that CT occurs from Ni atoms to Au atoms in nAu/Ni(111), which is named CT1 hereinafter. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), the sum of charges of nAu atoms gets more negative and the negative charge increases linearly with increasing Au content. As a result of the CT1, the d-valence band center (ɛ dc-VB) and the Fermi level (εF) lower in energy with increasing Au content (Fig. 7(b)); see Table S9 of the SI for their values. Note that the Au coverage in 9Au/Ni(111)L is the same as that in 4Au/Ni(111)S. In the 9Au/Ni(111)L case, the negative charge per one Au atom is –0.43 e and the ɛ dc-VB is –7.50 eV (Table S9 of the SI), which are almost the same as –0.42 e and –7.48 eV in the 4Au/Ni(111)S case [54], respectively. These results indicate that the (4 × 4) supercell reproduces the CT interaction and the ɛ dc-VB value of the (6 × 6) supercell of Ni(111)L, suggesting strongly that the Ni(111)S is a reasonable model. Although the Fermi level linearly lowers in energy with increasing Au content, the Fermi level is not very sensitive to the Au content. This is reasonable because the Fermi level is determined by the valence band of Ni atoms at the highest energy and nAu/Ni(111)L always contains a lot of Ni atoms. NO, CO, O, and N species are adsorbed on nAu/Ni(111)L (n = 0 ∼ 4, 6, 8, 9, and 11) at 3NiHf sites, where we excluded the n = 12 case because 3NiHf site disappears due to the presence of overly many Au atoms on the surface (Scheme 1(b)) and the adsorption occurs at 2 NiB sites in 12Au/Ni(111)L. All the BE (NO), BE (CO)(O), and BE (2N) values get less negative with increasing Au content (Fig. 7(c)), where BE (CO)(O) means the stabilization energy by adsorptions of CO molecule and O atom. These results indicate that the presence of Au atoms weakens the interaction between these adsorbates and the surface. Because these adsorbates are negatively charged and these species interact with Ni atoms, the CT1 from Ni atoms to Au atom(s) weakens the CT from Ni atoms to these adsorbates (named CT2). Consequently, these adsorption energies decrease with increasing Au atoms. The E a values for N–O bond cleavage, CO2 formation, and N2 formation (named E a(N–O), E a(CO2), and E a(N2), respectively) are plotted against the εdc-VB value in Fig. 7(d); note that these E a values are not the same as those in the catalytic reaction because other species are adsorbed to the surface in the catalytic reaction but not here; in other words, these values are useful for discussing the effects of Au coverage on the E a value of each elementary reaction step. The E a(N–O) value gradually increases but the E a(CO2) and E a(N2) values gradually decrease as the number of Au atoms (n) increases. These changes arise from the energy lowering of εdc-VB with increasing Au atoms, as follows: Because the CT2 must occur from the metal surface to NO in the N–O bond cleavage, the energy lowering of εd c -VB weakens the CT2 to increase the E a(N–O) value. On the other hand, CO2 and N2 formations occur with weakening of CT2 from the metal surface to adsorbates. Upon going from n = 0 to n = 9, the εd c -VB value lowers in energy to weaken the CT2 and decrease the E a(CO2) and E a(N2) values. It is noted that the E a values for the N2 and CO2 formations steeply decrease but the E a value for N–O bond cleavage moderately increases upon going from n = 9 to n = 11. These steep changes in the E a(CO2) and E a(N2) values arise from the constraint in the adsorption site, as follows; when n = 9, two N atoms are adsorbed at the distant Hf sites from each other and the CO and O atom are adsorbed at the distant Hf sites from each other, as shown in Figs. S16 and S17 of the SI. When n = 11, however, two N atoms must be adsorbed at the Hf sites neighboring to each other, and CO molecule and O atom must be adsorbed at the Hf sites neighboring to each other due to the limit of adsorption sites. In other words, when going from 9Au/Ni(111)L to 11Au/Ni(111)L, not only the εdc-VB value lowers in energy but also the two adsorption sites of N atoms get close to each other. As a result, the BE values of N, O, and CO species decrease very much and accordingly the E a(CO2) and E a(N2) values decrease very much when n = 11 (Fig. 7(d)). Here, we wish to discuss comparisons of these computational results with experimental findings. The roles of Au in promoting N2 formation was experimentally observed by Watanabe et al. [38]. They reported that the activation energy for N2 formation decreases by using Au-Ni alloy, which is consistent with our result showing that the E a value decreases from 1.86 eV (n = 0) to 1.61 eV (n = 9) with increasing Au atoms from 0 to 9, as shown in Fig. 7(d). In conclusion, the presence of Au atoms in Ni(111) lowers the ε d -VB value in energy, because CT1 occurs from Ni atoms to Au atoms. As a result, the N2 and CO2 formations are accelerated but the N–O bond cleavage is suppressed by Au atoms. Thus, the overly large Au content is not good. The optimal Au content is estimated to be around n = 9 to 10 (the Au coverage = 25 % to 28 %), as shown in Fig. 7(d); because this optimal Au coverage was obtained from model reactions and the coverage of adsorbates is larger in a real system than in this model system, the optimal Au content in the real system would be different from this value. However, it is true that the catalytic activity is the highest at some optimal Au content because the E a value of N–O bond cleavage increases and those of N2 and CO2 formations decrease. 4.5 NO-CO reaction on Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)S catalysts with two adsorbed N atoms As discussed above and shown by Figs. 2, 3, and 5(a), the (N)2-adsorbed system 12A is produced under the rich conditions. Because NO adsorption occurs with a significantly negative ΔG value, an (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed system is readily produced. The next step is either N2 formation or N−O bond cleavage. In this section, we investigated these two possibilities using Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S catalysts with two N atoms adsorbed on the surface; the (N)2-adsorbed system of the Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)S catalysts are named 2N/Ni(111)S and 2N + nAu/Ni(111)S, respectively. The energy profiles by the 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S catalyst are shown in Fig. 8 , where all geometry changes and the energy changes of the other catalytic systems are presented in Figs. S18–S24 of the SI. 4.5.1 N−O Bond cleavage vs N2 formation on Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S with two adsorbed N atoms Two NO molecules are adsorbed on the 2N/Ni(111)S 1Ni+2N and 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S 1Au+2N at the 3NiH sites with ΔG values of –4.07 eV and –3.87 eV to afford (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed systems 2Ni+2N and 2Au+2N , respectively, as shown in Fig. S18 of the SI and Fig. 8, respectively. These ΔG values are similar to or slightly less negative than those of the Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S catalysts (Fig. 1). In the 2N/Ni(111)S case, the first and the second N–O bond cleavages occur through transition states TS(2/3)Ni+2N and TS(3/4)Ni+2N with moderate E a values of 1.31 eV and 1.48 eV and moderate E r values of –0.64 eV and –0.47 eV, respectively. Although the E a value for the first N–O bond cleavage is similar between the Ni(111)S and 2N/Ni(111)S catalysts, the E a value of the second N–O bond cleavage is larger than that by the Ni(111)S catalyst and both E r values for the first and second N–O bond cleavages by the 2N/Ni(111)S catalyst are less negative than by the Ni(111)S catalyst (Fig. 1). In the 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S case, the first and second N–O bond cleavages occur with somewhat larger E a values (1.48 eV and 1.86 eV, respectively, in Fig. 8) and less negative (or more positive) E r values than in the 2Au/Ni(111)S case (Fig. 1). These results indicate that two adsorbed N atoms moderately suppress the NO adsorption and somewhat suppress N–O bond cleavage by the 2N/Ni(111)S and 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S catalysts. Because (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed systems 2Ni+2N and 2Au+2N undergo either N2 formation or N−O bond cleavage, we have to investigate which of N–O bond cleavage and N2 formation occurs as the next step. Starting from the (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed systems 22N and 2Au+2N , N2 formation occurs with E a values of 1.90 eV to 1.96 eV depending on the number of Au atoms, which is larger than those (1.31 eV to 1.85 eV depending on the number of Au atoms) of the N–O bond cleavage; details are shown in Table S10 of the SI. Therefore, it should be concluded that starting from the (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed systems 22N and 2Au+2N , not N2 formation but N–O bond cleavage occurs to afford (N)4(O)2-adsorbed systems 4Ni+2N and 4Au+2N . Under the rich conditions, CO adsorption followed by CO2 formation occurs to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system, as described above. Therefore, the second catalytic cycle starts with the (N)2-adsorbed system under the rich conditions. Although there exists one possibility that N2 formation occurs starting from the (N)4(O)2-adsorbed system under the lean conditions, we did not discuss the reaction under the lean conditions because the (N)2-adsorbed system is formed under the rich conditions. 4.5.2 Formations of CO2 and N2 on Ni(111)S and 2Au/Ni(111)S with two adsorbed N atoms Starting from 4Ni+2N (4Au+2N ), the first CO molecule is adsorbed on the catalyst surface to afford an (N)4(O)2(CO)-adsorbed system 5Ni+2N (5Au+2N ) with a ΔG value of –0.87 eV (–1.30 eV), where in parentheses are E a or ΔG value for 2N + nAu/Ni(111)S hereinafter; Figures S18 and S19 of the SI present geometry and energy changes by the 2N + Ni(111)S catalyst, respectively, and Figs. 8 and Fig. S24 of the SI present those by the 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S catalyst. Starting from 5Ni+2N (5Au+2N ), CO2 formation occurs with an E a value of 1.45 eV (1.39 eV) to afford (N)4(O)(CO2)-adsorbed system 6A-Ni+2N (6A-Au+2N ). Although these E a values are moderate, these values are larger than the CO desorption energy, leading to the conclusion that the CO2 formation is possible to occur under the rich conditions but is not under the lean conditions like in the Ni(111)S and nAu/Ni(111)S cases. In the 2N + Ni(111)S case (2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S), N2 formation occurs with an E a value of 1.59 eV or 1.70 eV (1.45 eV or 1.39 eV) before or after CO adsorption, respectively, via TS(4/12)Ni+2N and TS(5/6)B-Ni+2N (TS(4/12)Au+2N and TS(5/6)B-Au+2N ). These E a values are larger than those (1.46 eV and 1.39 eV for the 2N/Ni(111)S and 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S, respectively) of the CO2 formation, indicating that not N2 formation but CO2 formation occurs to afford an (N)4(O)-adsorbed systems 7A-Ni+2N (7A-Au+2N ) under the rich conditions. The second CO molecule is adsorbed to 7A-Ni+2N (7A-Au+2N ) to afford an (N)4(O)(CO)-adsorbed system 8A-Ni+2N (8A-Au+2N ) with a ΔG value of –1.23 eV (–1.20 eV). The second CO2 formation occurs via TS(8/9)A-Ni+2N (TS(8/9)A-Au+2N ) to afford an (N)4-adsorbed 9A-Ni+2N (9A-Au+2N ) with an E a value of 1.29 eV (1.42 eV). These E a values are smaller than those (1.56 eV and 1.64 eV for the 2N/Ni(111)S and 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S, respectively) of the N2 formation via TS(8/9)B-Ni+2N and TS(8/9)B-Au+2N . These results lead to the conclusion that the second CO2 formation occurs more easily than the N2 formation under the rich conditions. Starting from the (N)4-adsorbed system 10Ni+2N (10Au+2N ), N2 formation occurs as the last step with an E a value of 1.90 eV (1.75 eV) to afford an (N)2-adsorbed system 1Ni+2N (1Au+2N ). Under the lean conditions, N2 formation occurs with an E a value of 1.59 eV (1.45 eV) via TS(4/12)B-Ni+2N (TS(4/12)B-Au+2N ) to afford an (N2)(N)2(O)2-adsorbed system 12B-Ni+2N (12Au-Ni+2N ) (Figs. 8 and Fig. S18 of the SI). Although the other possible elementary steps are shown in Fig. 8, we stop to discuss those steps under the lean conditions because the (N)2-adsorbed catalysts 2N/Ni(111)S 1Ni+2N and 2N + 2Au/Ni(111)S 1Au+2N are formed under the rich conditions. Similar results are obtained for the 2N + Au/Ni(111)S and 2N + 3Au/Ni(111)S catalysts under the rich conditions but discussion is omitted here to avoid almost the same explanation; Figs. S20 to S23 of the SI present those results. 4.5.3 E a values of N2 formation and N–O bond cleavage vs Au content on the surface Because the (N)2-adsorbed system is formed under the rich conditions, the E a values for N2 formation and N–O bond cleavage under the rich conditions are plotted against the number of Au atoms on the 2N + nAu/Ni(111)S catalyst, as shown in Fig. 9 (a), where that for the CO2 formation is omitted for brevity because the CO2 formation is not a rate-determining step; recall that the E a value of CO2 formation is smaller than that of N2 formation. Apparently, the E a value for the N−O bond cleavage increases but that for the N2 formation decreases with increasing Au atoms like in the nAu/Ni(111)S case. Interestingly, these two relations cross each other around n = 1 unlike in the nAu/Ni(111)S case, indicating that the volcano plot exists for the relation between the catalytic activity and the Au content and the optimal Au content is n = 1, which corresponds to the Au content of 6 % to 7 %. This result differs from that obtained for nAu/Ni(111)S without adsorbed N atoms (Fig. 5) in which the E a value for N2 formation always exists above that for N–O bond cleavage for n = 0 to 3 and therefore the best Au content is larger than n = 3 (the Au coverage > ca. 19 %). The difference between nAu/Ni(111)S and 2N + nAu/Ni(111)S is understood on the basis of the d-valence band center (εdc-VB). As shown in Fig. 9(b), the Fermi level εF and the d-valence band center εd-VB of 2N + nAu/Ni(111)S are found at much lower energies than those of nAu/Ni(111)S. This is reasonable because the adsorbed N atoms withdraw electron density from nAu/Ni(111)S. This means that two adsorbed N atoms on the Ni(111) surface lower considerably the εF and εdc-VB values in energy. As a result, the presence of fewer Au atoms on the Ni(111) with adsorbed N atoms is enough to exhibit the maximum catalytic activity than on the Ni(111) without adsorbed N atom. In conclusion, the NO adsorption followed by the N–O bond cleavage more easily occurs than the N2 formation starting from the (N)2-adsorbed system. Therefore, the second catalytic cycle starts with the catalyst possessing two adsorbed N atoms under the rich conditions. In such a case, the large Au content is not necessary. 5 Conclusions The catalytic cycle of NO-CO reaction on Ni-Au SAAs nAu/Ni(111)S (n = 0 ∼ 3) were theoretically investigated using DFT calculations on the slab model to elucidate what roles Au atoms play in Ni-Au SAA catalysts for the NO-CO reaction. Important findings are summarized below: (i) The N–O bond of adsorbed NO molecule is cleaved with a small E a value and a considerably negative E r value. (ii) N2O formation is difficult to occur because this reaction is considerably endothermic and needs a larger E a value than that of the second N–O bond cleavage of adsorbed NO molecule, which is consistent with the experimental observation that the yield of N2O is tiny [38]. (iii) Starting from the (N)2(O)2(CO)-adsorbed system, the E a value of CO2 formation is smaller than that of N2 formation but slightly larger than CO desorption energy. Thus, it is concluded that CO2 formation does not occur and only N2 formation can occur under the lean conditions to afford (O)2-adsorbed surface, as experimentally observed [38–40]; recall that the CO concentration is small under the lean conditions, the CO adsorption is suppressed by the NO adsorption due to the smaller adsorption energy of CO than that of NO, and the CO desorption energy is smaller than the E a value for CO2 formation. (iv) Under the rich conditions, CO2 formation occurs two times more easily than N2 formation, to afford (N)2-adsorbed system, and the last step is N2 formation, which is a rate-limiting step. This is consistent with the experimental result showing that the N2 formation needs higher temperatures than the other reactions such as CO2 formation [38–40]. (v) The presence of Au atoms in Ni-Au SAAs increases the E a value of N–O bond cleavage but decreases the E a values of CO2 formation and N2 formation because the d-valence band center lowers in energy by the presence of Au atoms. Thus, the volcano plot between the catalytic activity and the Au content is obtained and the optimal Au content is about 25 % to 28 % (9Au/Ni(111)L to 10Au/Ni(111)L) for the first catalytic cycle starting from the clean surface without adsorbed N atom. (vi) Because NO adsorption to the (N)2-adsorbed nAu/Ni(111)S occurs with a significantly negative ΔG value and N–O bond cleavage occurs more easily than does N2 formation starting from the (N)2(NO)-adsorbed nAu/Ni(111)S, the next catalytic cycle starts with the NO adsorption to the (N)2-adsorbed nAu/Ni(111)S catalyst. In this case, the NO-CO reaction can occur with a smaller E a value than in the first catalytic cycle starting from the clean surface without adsorbed N atoms. And, (vii) when N atoms remain on the catalyst surface, d-valence band center lowers in energy because adsorbed N atoms withdraw electron density from Ni(111) surface, and therefore the optimum Au content decreases to about 6 % to 7 % for the second catalytic cycle. In addition, two points are emphasized here; (a) although Au atoms on the surface do not directly participate in NO-CO reaction except that Au atoms suppress CO and NO adsorptions around Au atoms, Au atoms lower d-valence band center by CT1 from Ni atoms to Au atoms, to accelerate N2 and CO2 formations but suppress N–O bond cleavage, and (b) not nAu/Ni(111) but 2N + nAu/Ni(111) with adsorbed N atoms is an active species for the NO-CO reaction. At the last, we wish to mention that the present model differs from a real system due to a much smaller coverage of adsorbates on the surface. This means that adsorbate-induced changes in electronic structure of Ni surface, limited adsorption sites, and lateral interaction are missing in the present model: For instance, the optimal Au content would decrease from the present value when electron-withdrawing species are co-adsorbed on the catalyst. However, it is likely that the present model reproduces the effects of Au atoms on the Ni-catalyzed NO-CO reaction; for instance, it is true that the presence of Au atoms decreases the activation energies of N2 and CO2 formations and increases the activation energy of N−O bond cleavage. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom alloy (SAA) attracts great interest recently as excellent heterogeneous catalyst. Herein, the catalysis of Ni-based Au SAA for NO-CO reaction is investigated using DFT calculations. Under lean conditions, N2 formation occurs to produce NiOx surface, as observed experimentally, because CO2 formation cannot occur due to easy desorption of CO. Under rich conditions, CO2 formation occurs with small E a value to afford (N)2-adsorbed surface. Next catalytic cycle starts with (N)2(NO)2-adsorbed surface because N2 formation needs larger E a value but NO adsorption readily occurs with considerable energy stabilization. As Au-content increases, d-valence-band center lowers in energy to increase activation barrier for N–O bond cleavage of NO but decrease those of CO2 and N2 formations. Thus, rate-limiting step is N2 formation in low Au-content but N–O bond cleavage in high Au-content. A volcano-plot is presented against Au-content. The optimal Au-content is about 6 % on catalyst surface.
coredata.dc:title: Catalysis of Nickel-Based gold single-atom alloy for NO-CO reaction: Theoretical insight into role of gold atom in enhancing catalytic activity
